channel.title: +MT on Vishvas's notes

item.title: Peopling
item.description:
Source: TW

The interesting thing about the brutal landscape of Greenland is the number of times it was re-colonized by genetically distinct people starting from as early 2500 BCE! The war-like Scandis +++(=scandinavians)+++ had a tough time dealing with the whale-killing Inuits. We would posit that genetic factors allowed to Inuit coming from Alaska to ultimately triumph.

People/Culture Origin Period Legacy
Independence I Northern Canada (Arctic Archipelago) c. 2500-1800 BCE Part of the Paleo-Inuit tradition. Genetically distinct from modern Inuit; descendants of a separate migration from Siberia.
Saqqaq Northern Canada / Alaska c. 2400-800 BCE Also Paleo-Inuit. DNA shows they are related to Siberian Chukchi and Koryak peoples, but not to modern Inuit.
Independence II Northern Canada c. 800-1 BCE Paleo-Inuit. Often grouped with the early Dorset culture; specialized in hunting muskox and seal in the extreme north.
Early Dorset Northern Canada c. 700 BCE-200 CE Paleo-Inuit. Famous for the “Arctic Small Tool Tradition.” Lived primarily along the west and east coasts.
Late Dorset Northern Canada (Ellesmere Island) c. 700-1300 CE The last of the Paleo-Inuit. Known to modern Inuit legends as the Tuniitâ€”a shy but powerful people eventually replaced.
Norse (Vikings) Iceland / Norway c. 985-1450 CE Scandinavian (European). Founded by Erik the Red. Established farming communities but disappeared during the “Little Ice Age.”
Thule (Inuit) Northern Alaska c. 1200 CE-Present Inuit. Direct ancestors of modern Greenlanders. Brought advanced technologies like the Umiak and dog sleds.
